summary: This is an email from a DOJ attaché/magistrate at the U.S. Embassy in Paris to U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) personnel, referring a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request from French authorities regarding their investigation of Jean-Luc Brunel, who was recently arrested in Paris. The sender notes they have been in touch about the Ghislaine Maxwell bail proceedings.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: French modeling agent and associate of Jeffrey Epstein, recently arrested and placed under examination in Paris as part of a French investigation. An MLAT request from France regarding him is being referred to the SDNY.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned indirectly as the sender has been in touch with the recipients about her bail proceedings. She is a central figure in the Epstein case.

connections.description: Both are key figures in the Epstein network. The document contextually links them as subjects of related legal proceedings (Brunel's investigation in France, Maxwell's bail proceedings in the U.S.).

events.title: Arrest of Jean-Luc Brunel in Paris
events.description: Jean-Luc Brunel was recently arrested and placed under examination by French authorities in Paris as part of their investigation.

events.title: Referral of MLAT Request from France
events.description: A DOJ attaché at the U.S. Embassy in Paris sends an email to the SDNY, formally referring a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request from French authorities concerning their investigation of Jean-Luc Brunel.

keyFacts: French authorities were actively investigating Jean-Luc Brunel and had recently arrested him in Paris as of December 2020.

The U.S. Department of Justice, via an attaché at the U.S. Embassy in Paris, was facilitating international legal cooperation by referring a French MLAT request regarding Brunel to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY).
The SDNY was concurrently handling the bail proceedings for Ghislaine Maxwell, indicating parallel legal tracks for key Epstein associates in different jurisdictions.
The communication demonstrates ongoing international coordination between U.S. and French law enforcement regarding the Epstein network.
